channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2017 The New York Times Company

item.title: Thousands Once Spoke His Language in the Amazon. Now, He’s the Only One.
item.media:description: Amadeo fishing near Intuto. The Peruvian Amazon was once a vast linguistic repository, but in the last century at least 37 languages have disappeared in Peru alone.
item.media:credit: Ben C. Solomon/The New York Times
item.description: The Taushiro tribe vanished into the jungles of the Amazon basin in Peru generations ago. Amadeo García García is now the last native speaker of their language.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS CASEY

item.title: One Man’s Stand Against Junk Food as Diabetes Climbs Across India
item.media:description: Rahul Verma distributing the Indian dish khichdi, a mixture of rice, lentils and vegetables, to patients outside a hospital in New Dehli. Mr. Verma has taken a stand against junk food in India, where people are more likely to develop diabetes from weight gain than people in other regions.
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times.
item.description: India is “sitting on a volcano” of diabetes. A father’s effort to ban junk food sales in and near schools aims to change what children eat.
item.dc:creator: GEETA ANAND

item.title: North Korea Won’t Stop Its Arms Tests Anytime Soon, South Warns
item.media:description: North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-un, addressed a ruling party conference in Pyongyang, the capital, on Saturday, according to the state news agency.
item.media:credit: Korean Central News Agency, via Associated Press
item.description: Government and private analysts expect the North to bolster its nuclear and long-range missile capabilities in 2018 to gain leverage with Washington.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament

item.title: Cross-Border Clashes in Kashmir Leave 7 Soldiers Dead
item.media:description: The funeral of a suspected Pakistan-based militant, who according to the local news media was killed in a gun battle with Indian security forces, in Kashmir on Tuesday.
item.description: On the same day Pakistan allowed an Indian accused of spying a visit from his family, three Pakistani soldiers were killed in Kashmir.
item.dc:creator: SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: In Tangled Afghan War, a Thin Line of Defense Against ISIS
item.media:description: Some of the men in charge of the war for the government in Khogyani, in eastern Afghanistan.
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.description: The Islamic State in eastern Afghanistan has survived intense pressure from American airstrikes and raids by United States and Afghan forces.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: For One Far-Right Politician, Forgetting Germany’s Past Just Got Harder
item.media:description: A political art group built a replica of the Berlin Holocaust Memorial in Bornhagen, Germany. Next door is the home of Björn Höcke, a far-right politician who called the memorial “a monument of shame.”
item.media:credit: Gordon Welters for The New York Times
item.description: Björn Höcke declared Berlin’s Holocaust Memorial a “Monument of Shame.” So a German artist collective built one to scale, right outside his bedroom window.
item.dc:creator: KATRIN BENNHOLD

item.title: Taking Credit for U.N. Budget Cut, Trump’s Envoy Hints at More to Come
item.media:description: The American ambassador to the United Nations, Nikki R. Haley, right, at the General Assembly last week.
item.description: Ambassador Nikki R. Haley coupled her applause for a $285 million cut in the 2018-2019 budget with a suggestion that she would seek further reductions.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Royal Navy Escorts Russian Warship Near U.K.
item.media:description: An image from an infrared camera of the Royal Navy frigate St. Albans, in the foreground, escorting the Russian warship Admiral Gorshkov through the North Sea.
item.media:credit: British Royal Navy, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: “Britain will never be intimidated when it comes to protecting our country, our people, and our national interests,” Defense Secretary Gavin Williamson said.
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU

item.title: Chinese Activist Sentenced to 8 Years in Prison for Shaming Officials
item.media:description: The human rights activist Wu Gan, in a still image taken from a YouTube video.
item.description: Under President Xi Jinping, determined activists like Wu Gan, who once survived at the edges of official tolerance, have come under concerted attack.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Global Health: Measles Deaths Fall to a Record Low Worldwide
item.media:description: A child receiving measles vaccine in a refugee camp in Bangladesh last month. Annual deaths from measles have fallen below 100,000 worldwide, according to the World Health Organization.
item.description: Thanks to vaccines, the disease — which not long ago killed over 2 million children a year — now kills fewer than 100,000, the W.H.O. reported.
item.dc:creator: DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.

item.title: Laundry Day Around the World
item.description: From handwashing to laundromats, people in different parts of the world gather together to do laundry. Enter those spaces in 360 video.

item.title: The Last Taushiro
item.description: Amadeo García García is the last man to speak his language. When he goes, an entire culture will disappear. We went to find him.

item.title: Cultured Traveler: Francine Prose’s Oaxaca: An Immersion Course in Mexico’s Delights
item.media:description: People dressed in traditional attire prepare for a parade in front of the Templo de Santo Domingo de Guzmán.
item.media:credit: Brett Gundlock for The New York Times
item.description: Oaxaca has become popular during the holiday season when the temperate weather, the food and the festive spirit attract travelers from near and far.
item.dc:creator: FRANCINE PROSE

item.title: International Herald Tribune: 1917: Americans Skate in No Man’s Land and Bait Enemy
item.description: American troops in World War I risked enemy fire to skate on a frozen canal in No Man’s Land. When the Germans began to shoot, the Americans took quick action to avoid being hit.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Peru in Uproar After Fujimori, a Rights Violator, Gets Medical Pardon
item.media:description: Former President Alberto Fujimori of Peru at a court hearing in Lima in 2013. He was granted a medical pardon on Sunday.
item.description: Former President Alberto Fujimori was not eligible for such treatment because of the nature of his crimes, legal experts in Peru said.
item.dc:creator: ANDREA ZARATE
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: The Roots of Poland’s Defiance of the European Union
item.media:description: Poles demonstrated with Polish and European Union flags and copies of the Constitution in front of the presidential palace in Warsaw last month to protest the new judicial laws.
item.description: The bloc for the first time invoked a rule that could strip Poland of its voting rights after the president signed measures that critics say threaten the rule of law.
item.dc:creator: MARC SANTORA

item.title: China’s New Lenders Collect Invasive Data and Offer Billions. Beijing Is Worried.
item.media:description: Bai Shichao, a delivery man in Beijing, in his unheated room on the outskirts of Beijing. Mr. Bai racked up about $5,000 in debt from various Chinese online lending platforms.
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.description: Government officials are moving to curb a new generation of businesses that make personal loans online, amid concerns about privacy and rising debt.
item.dc:creator: ALEXANDRA STEVENSON and CAO LI

item.title: Russia Bars Kremlin Critic From Running for President
item.media:description: The Russian opposition leader Aleksei A. Navalny, center, submitted documents to register as a presidential candidate at the Central Election Commission in Moscow on Sunday. His application was denied on Monday.
item.description: Aleksei A. Navalny, the Kremlin’s leading critic, was barred from running for president, prompting him to urge his supporters to boycott the vote and join street protests.
item.dc:creator: IVAN NECHEPURENKO

item.title: Queen Praises U.K. Terrorism Survivors in Christmas Message
item.media:description: Queen Elizabeth II at Buckingham Palace in London this month after recording her Christmas Day message, which included only a gentle reference to Prince Harry’s engagement to the American actress Meghan Markle.
item.description: The annual broadcast, 60 years after the monarch’s first televised address, sought to provide solace after a series of tragedies in the country.
item.dc:creator: PETER ROBINS
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain

item.title: On Christmas Day, Pope Francis Prays for Peace in an Uneasy World
item.media:description: Pope Francis delivering the traditional Urbi et Orbi blessing from a balcony overlooking St. Peter’s Square in the Vatican on Monday.
item.description: The pope’s Urbi et Orbi address read like a litany of global conflicts, with remarks noting tensions in the Middle East, Europe and beyond.
item.dc:creator: JASON HOROWITZ

item.title: Manila Journal: Duterte Threatens to Dethrone the Jeepney as King of Filipino Roads
item.media:description: Jeepneys, patterned after World War II-era American jeeps and painted in brash designs, are a staple of Manila’s packed, polluted streets.
item.media:credit: Jes Aznar for The New York Times
item.description: Jeepneys are the most popular mode of transportation in the Philippines. But a new government policy could spell the end of the country’s iconic auto.
item.dc:creator: AURORA ALMENDRAL

item.title: Duterte’s Son Quits Post After Battling Daughter on Social Media
item.media:description: Paolo Duterte, son of President Rodrigo Duterte, at a Senate hearing in Manila in September, when he was vice mayor of Davao in the southern Philippines.
item.description: Paolo Duterte’s daughter implied on Twitter that her father had beaten her, causing the vice mayor to strike back on Facebook.
item.dc:creator: GERRY MULLANY

item.title: Pakistani Women Seize Film Dispute as Chance to Discuss Rape and Injustice
item.media:description: In the Pakistani film “Verna,” Mahira Khan plays a teacher who is raped by the son of a powerful politician. The movie was banned by Pakistan’s censors, but an appellate panel reversed that decision after a public outcry.
item.description: A film about an abduction case was banned by Pakistan’s censors, but a public outcry, fueled by a social media campaign, helped overturn the ruling.
item.dc:creator: MEHREEN ZAHRA-MALIK

item.title: Using Billions in Government Cash, Mexico Controls News Media
item.media:description: A news conference in Mexico City. The president’s administration has spent nearly $2 billion on advertising in the past five years.
item.description: Federal and state officials wield huge budgets for public advertising to dictate news coverage, routinely telling outlets what they should — and should not — report.
item.dc:creator: AZAM AHMED

item.title: Guatemala Will Move Its Israel Embassy to Jerusalem, Following Trump’s Lead
item.media:description: President Jimmy Morales of Guatemala, left, and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israeli after signing agreements in Jerusalem last year.
item.description: The nation is the first to follow President Trump in deciding to change the site of its embassy from Tel Aviv.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETH MALKIN

item.title: Peru’s President Pardons Alberto Fujimori, Enraging Critics
item.media:description: Alberto Fujimori, the former president of Peru, at his last trial in Lima, in 2014.
item.description: Mr. Fujimori, who was president from 1990 to 2000, was serving a 25-year term for human rights abuses.
item.dc:creator: ANDREA ZARATE and SEWELL CHAN
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Why Saad Hariri Had That Strange Sojourn in Saudi Arabia
item.media:description: Saad Hariri arriving at Beirut’s international airport last month, weeks after announcing his resignation as Lebanon’s prime minister in Saudi Arabia.
item.description: Mr. Hariri, Lebanon’s prime minister, expected the royal treatment when he was summoned to Riyadh. Instead, he was told to resign. Here is the back story.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD and MARIA ABI-HABIB

item.title: Prince Harry Is Getting Married. Time for Themed Mugs and Nightclub Tours.
item.media:description: Royal memorabilia are popular items. A portion of Margaret Tyler’s collection at her home in London.
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.description: Britain’s monarchy can be big money. And with a royal wedding next year, tour groups, ceramics makers and other companies are trying to capitalize.
item.dc:creator: AMIE TSANG

item.title: Pope Francis Puts Focus on Refugees in Christmas Eve Mass
item.media:description: Pope Francis celebrated the Christmas Eve Mass in St. Peter's Basilica at the Vatican on Sunday.
item.description: At a Mass that amplifies his voice around the globe, Francis evoked a parallel between the travails of migrants and those of the biblical holy family.
item.dc:creator: JASON HOROWITZ

item.title: Navalny Is Nominated by Hundreds to Challenge Putin for Russian Presidency
item.media:description: The Russian opposition leader Aleksei Navalny addressing supporters in Moscow on Sunday.
item.description: The move allows Aleksei Navalny to ready the endorsement papers required for candidacy, putting pressure on the Kremlin to allow one of the Russian president’s most formidable foes to run.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: In Ireland, a Same-Sex Marriage With a Tax Benefit
item.media:description: Matt Murphy, 82, left, and Michael O’Sullivan, 58, decided to marry when they discovered the tax implications of Mr. Murphy bequeathing his home to Mr. O’Sullivan.
item.description: Matt Murphy, 82, and Michael O’Sullivan, 58, who are close friends, married to avoid inheritance tax.
item.dc:creator: ED O’LOUGHLIN
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships

item.title: Australia Diary: Christmas in ’Straya
item.description: A naughty Santa, some nice neighbors and a white lie by the pool.
item.dc:creator: DIANA OLIVA CAVE

item.title: One Target in Beijing’s Migrant Crackdown: Schoolchildren
item.media:description: A class at the Shijingshan Huangzhuang School in southern Beijing in mid-December. The school is slated for demolition next month.
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.description: The demolition of schools for migrant children has driven 15,000 students out of their classrooms, depriving many of a chance at an education.
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ and IRIS ZHAO

item.title: Taken From Ukraine’s War Zone, Grenades Are Used in Crimes, Too
item.media:description: A clash with protesters in Kiev, Ukraine, in 2015. A hand grenade that day killed four police officers and wounded 141 people.
item.description: The weapons are becoming an increasingly common feature in criminal activities including domestic violence and bank robberies.
item.dc:creator: IULIIA MENDEL

item.title: How Do You Keep an Elephant Warm? Knit a Giant Blanket
item.media:description: Baby elephants in Myanmar wearing blankets during a cold spell.
item.description: When an unexpected cold spell hit Myanmar, caretakers of orphaned animals pulled out giant blankets that had been knitted for them.
item.dc:creator: YONETTE JOSEPH

item.title: North Korea Calls U.N. Sanctions an ‘Act of War’
item.media:description: North Koreans watching coverage of a missile test launch in Pyongyang in July. North Korea said on Sunday that the United Nations Security Council’s latest sanctions were tantamount to a blockade.
item.description: Pyongyang vowed revenge on the United States, which sponsored the resolution, and the Security Council members that approved the measure.
item.dc:creator: RUSSELL GOLDMAN
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament

item.title: ‘We Are Afraid of Christmas’: Tensions Dampen Holiday in India
item.media:description: A Christmas display at a New Delhi mall. Though Christians are a small minority in India, celebrating the holiday appeals to many outside the faith.
item.description: Christmas is becoming big business in India, where it has a cosmopolitan appeal to people of many faiths. But far-right Hindu groups have put the holiday in their cross hairs.
item.dc:creator: KAI SCHULTZ and SUHASINI RAJ

item.title: American ISIS Suspect Held in Iraq Has Right to Lawyer, Judge Rules
item.media:description: Suspected Islamic State fighters detained at a courthouse in Qaraqosh, Iraq, this year. A federal judge has ruled that an American citizen detained as an “enemy combatant” has the right to a lawyer.
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.description: An American citizen who has been imprisoned in military custody as an “enemy combatant” for months must be allowed to talk with an A.C.L.U. lawyer.
item.dc:creator: CHARLIE SAVAGE
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Dozens Feared Dead in Fire at Philippines Mall
item.media:description: At least 37 people were trapped inside a burning shopping mall in the southern Philippines city of Davao. The cause of the fire remains unknown.
item.description: Firefighters recovered one body but have been unable to enter the mall in Davao City since the fire started on Saturday, officials said.
item.dc:creator: FELIPE VILLAMOR

item.title: The Hunt for ISIS Pivots to Remaining Pockets in Syria
item.media:description: Secretary of Defense James Mattis and Central Command Commander Gen. Joseph Votel discussed Washington’s military strategy in Syria during a briefing in April at the Pentagon in Washington. Mr. Votel said in an interview in Bahrain that American forces will remain in eastern Syria as long as needed to defeat the Islamic State.
item.description: The last phase of the American campaign against the caliphate is relying heavily on warplanes that are focused on an area half the size of Manhattan.
item.dc:creator: ERIC SCHMITT
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Russia Says U.S.-Supplied Weapons to Ukraine Could Escalate Conflict
item.media:description: A residential block damaged by shelling this week in the rebel-held town of Yasynuvata, Ukraine.
item.description: Russian officials said a decision by the United States to provide arms to Ukraine is dangerous as it will encourage Kiev to use force in eastern Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: ‘I’m Struggling to Survive’: For Rohingya Women, Abuse Continues in Camps
item.media:description: Rahima, 15, fled Myanmar in September. She was gang-raped by soldiers, one of whom bit her cheek, leaving a scar. “I don’t know why he bit me,” she said. “There are many things I don’t understand.”
item.media:credit: Tomas Munita for The New York Times
item.description: Even after escaping Myanmar, survivors of rape and other trauma find themselves still vulnerable and commodified in the brokenness of refugee life.
item.dc:creator: HANNAH BEECH
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Bus Plunges Into River in India, Killing Dozens
item.media:description: The bus being pulled from the Banas River after Saturday’s accident.
item.description: At least 33 people died when a bus careened off a bridge in the western Indian state of Rajasthan.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: In a First, U.N. Evacuates Dozens of Refugees from Libya to Italy
item.media:description: Dozens of vulnerable refugees and migrants arrived at the Pratica di Mare military airport near Rome on Friday.
item.description: The group of 162 refugees and migrants had been held in detention in bleak conditions. It is the first time the United Nations’ refugee agency has relocated people from Libya directly into Europe.
item.dc:creator: MEGAN SPECIA
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Yugoslavia Tribunal Leaves Rich Legacy, but ‘Immense’ Challenges Remain
item.media:description: António Guterres, the secretary general of the United Nations, speaking at the closing ceremony of the International Criminal Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia. “Accountability has taken root in our collective consciousness,” he said.
item.description: During its 24-year life, it indicted 161 people, heard from 5,000 witnesses and expanded international law. Justice, though, is still a “long-term undertaking.”
item.dc:creator: MARLISE SIMONS
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia

item.title: As Prince Accelerates Changes for Women, Saudis Adapt at Varied Pace
item.media:description: Men and women sit separately during a picnic at a park in Riyadh. In public spaces, people tend to follow rules limiting interactions between unrelated women and men. But in private, Saudis largely do as they please.
item.media:credit: Tasneem Alsultan for The New York Times
item.description: The dizzying changes put in place by Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman have the potential to radically change Saudi women’s lives, if the men in their lives don’t put on the brakes.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD and TASNEEM ALSULTAN

item.title: London Zoo Fire Kills Aardvark; 4 Meerkats Are Missing
item.media:description: Firefighters battling a blaze at the London Zoo on Saturday that engulfed a gift shop and cafe.
item.description: A 9-year-old aardvark named Misha died in the blaze, which engulfed a cafe and gift shop before 72 firefighters brought it under control on Saturday.
item.dc:creator: YONETTE JOSEPH

item.title: Yemen’s War Enters a Dark Stage as Rebels Squeeze the Capital
item.media:description: Houthi rebels at the Republican Palace that was destroyed by Saudi-led airstrikes this month in Sana, the Yemeni capital.
item.description: Many expected Yemen’s Houthi rebels to become vulnerable after they killed their most important ally. But weeks later, they are locking up their foes.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD and NOUR YOUSSEF
